title: WFU Agentic AI Workgroup
text:
Project instructions



This is a faculty/staff workgroup at Wake Forest University focused on agentic AI tools in the CLI. It is not a credit-bearing course — there are no grades, no formal assessment, and membership is rolling (participants join and leave at any time).

Audience: WFU faculty and staff with little or no CLI experience
Format: Weekly in-person meetings + async web content
Facilitator: Will Fleeson (Department of Psychology)
Deliverable: A Quarto website deployed to GitHub Pages




The workgroup moves participants from zero CLI knowledge toward independent use of agentic AI tools:

Navigate the file system and run commands in a terminal
Use Git and GitHub for version control and collaboration
Configure shell environments and dotfiles
Interact with Claude Code for agentic coding workflows
Access and configure APIs for AI services
Set up and use MCP servers for tool integration
Author reproducible documents with Markdown and Quarto




When writing tutorials, session notes, or resource pages:

Assume zero CLI knowledge. Define terms on first use. Explain what commands do before showing them.
Progressive difficulty. Early content covers basic navigation and file operations. Later content introduces Git, Claude Code, APIs, and MCPs.
Worked examples over abstractions. Show a concrete task, walk through the steps, then generalize. Avoid leading with theory.
Copy-paste friendly. Code blocks should be runnable as-is. Include expected output where helpful.
Platform awareness. Most participants use macOS, but some use Windows. Tutorials should default to macOS examples and note Windows differences (e.g., PowerShell vs bash, path separators, installer commands) in callouts or inline when behavior diverges.
No jargon without context. If a term is unavoidable, define it inline or link to the glossary.





Shell: bash (default macOS shell via Terminal.app or iTerm2)
Version control: Git + GitHub
AI tools: Claude Code (CLI), Anthropic API, MCP servers
Authoring: Markdown, Quarto (.qmd files)
Deployment: GitHub Pages via quarto publish gh-pages
Environment: Nix flake for reproducible development setup




index.qmd          — Landing page (welcome, meeting info, getting started)
about.qmd          — Purpose, learning goals, format, facilitator
sessions/          — Session notes, one file per meeting (date-based)
  index.qmd        — Session log, reverse chronological
tutorials/         — Self-contained topic tutorials
  index.qmd        — Tutorial catalog with difficulty indicators
  01-cli-basics.qmd
  02-working-with-paths.qmd
  03-shell-configuration.qmd
  04-git-fundamentals.qmd
  05-github-collaboration.qmd
  06-claude-code-intro.qmd
  07-apis-and-mcps.qmd
resources/         — Reference material
  index.qmd        — Resource hub
  cheatsheets.qmd
  tools.qmd
  troubleshooting.qmd
  glossary.qmd


Create sessions/YYYY-MM-DD.qmd with front matter:
---
title: "Session title"
date: "YYYY-MM-DD"
description: "Brief summary of what was covered."
---
The listing on sessions/index.qmd picks up new session files automatically.



Create tutorials/topic-name.qmd with front matter that includes categories (one of "Getting started", "Version control", or "AI tools"):
---
title: "Tutorial title"
description: "Brief description of the tutorial."
date: "YYYY-MM-DD"
categories: ["Getting started"]
---
The listing on tutorials/index.qmd picks up new tutorial files automatically.





Theme: flatly (Bootstrap-based, clean and readable)
Code blocks: Use code-copy: true and code-tools: true for interactive code
External links: Open in new window (link-external-newwindow: true)
Front matter: Every .qmd file needs title at minimum; tutorials should also have description and date
Callouts: Use Quarto callouts (.callout-note, .callout-tip, .callout-warning) for asides and important information
Images: Store in an images/ subdirectory relative to the page that uses them




Follow the conventions in the global ~/.claude/CLAUDE.md:

R: tidyverse, native pipe (|>), 2-space indent
Python: data science stack, ruff, 4-space indent
Bash: POSIX-compliant, 2-space indent
Line limit: 80 characters (except Markdown)
Naming: snake_case (functions/variables)
Lists: Use - not * or +
Conventional commits: type(scope): message




The specs/ directory contains planning, progress, and implementation documents for the workgroup. These files are excluded from the rendered site (via .gitignore and not being listed in _quarto.yml). They are internal project management documents.

title: WFU Agentic AI Workgroup
text: The specs/ directory contains planning, progress, and implementation documents for the workgroup. These files are excluded from the rendered site (via .gitignore and not being listed in _quarto.yml). They are internal project management documents.

title: APIs and MCPs
text:
APIs let you access AI models programmatically. MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers extend what AI assistants can do by connecting them to external tools and data sources. This tutorial covers API key management, basic API usage, and setting up MCP servers.
Prerequisites: Claude Code introduction Estimated time: 35 minutes






Note



Content in progress. Check back soon or attend a workgroup session for a guided walkthrough.

title: APIs and MCPs
text:
APIs let you access AI models programmatically. MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers extend what AI assistants can do by connecting them to external tools and data sources. This tutorial covers API key management, basic API usage, and setting up MCP servers.
Prerequisites: Claude Code introduction Estimated time: 35 minutes






Note



Content in progress. Check back soon or attend a workgroup session for a guided walkthrough.

title: Tutorials
text:
Work through these tutorials in order, or jump to whichever topic you need.


    
      
      
    








CLI basics



Getting started



Open a terminal, run your first commands, and work with files and directories.










Working with paths



Getting started



Understand absolute and relative paths, the home directory, and how to navigate the file system.










Shell configuration



Getting started



Customize your terminal with dotfiles, environment variables, and aliases.










Git fundamentals



Version control



Track changes to your files with Git: init, add, commit, log, and diff.










GitHub collaboration



Version control



Push code to GitHub, collaborate with pull requests, and review changes.










Claude Code introduction



AI tools



Install Claude Code, configure it for your projects, and start an agentic coding workflow.










APIs and MCPs



AI tools



Configure API keys for AI services and set up Model Context Protocol servers.





No matching items

title: GitHub collaboration
text:
GitHub hosts Git repositories online and provides tools for collaboration. This tutorial covers working with remote repositories, pushing and pulling changes, creating pull requests, and reviewing code.
Prerequisites: Git fundamentals Estimated time: 30 minutes






Note



Content in progress. Check back soon or attend a workgroup session for a guided walkthrough.

title: GitHub collaboration
text:
GitHub hosts Git repositories online and provides tools for collaboration. This tutorial covers working with remote repositories, pushing and pulling changes, creating pull requests, and reviewing code.
Prerequisites: Git fundamentals Estimated time: 30 minutes






Note



Content in progress. Check back soon or attend a workgroup session for a guided walkthrough.

title: Working with paths
text:
Paths tell the terminal where to find files. This tutorial covers the difference between absolute and relative paths, what the home directory is, and how to move around the file system confidently.
Prerequisites: CLI basics Estimated time: 20 minutes






Note



Content in progress. Check back soon or attend a workgroup session for a guided walkthrough.

title: Sessions
text:
Session notes are posted here after each weekly meeting, most recent first. Each entry includes a summary of what was covered, links to relevant tutorials, and any follow-up items.





Meeting Notes


Notes and materials from the AI Workgroup meeting held on February 6, 2026.

title: WFU Agentic AI Workgroup
text: This workgroup brings together Wake Forest University faculty and staff who want to learn how to use agentic AI tools from the command line. We start from scratch — no prior terminal experience required — and work our way toward using tools like Claude Code, APIs, and MCP servers in everyday academic workflows.

title: WFU Agentic AI Workgroup
text: This workgroup brings together Wake Forest University faculty and staff who want to learn how to use agentic AI tools from the command line. We start from scratch — no prior terminal experience required — and work our way toward using tools like Claude Code, APIs, and MCP servers in everyday academic workflows.

title: WFU Agentic AI Workgroup
text:
Meeting info

When: Weekly (see sessions for schedule)
Where: In person at WFU (location TBA)/ or via Zoom (link in calendar invite)
Who: Any WFU faculty or staff member — join anytime

title: WFU Agentic AI Workgroup
text:
Getting started
New to the workgroup? Start here:

CLI basics — Open a terminal and run your first commands
Working with paths — Navigate the file system with confidence
Shell configuration — Customize your terminal environment

Then move on to version control and AI tools when you’re ready.

title: Workgroup Implementation Details
text:
Workgroup: WFU Agentic AI Workgroup Status: Active Last Updated: 2026-02-06





Primary framework: Social constructivism — participants learn by doing, collaborating, and building on each other’s knowledge
Instructional model: Task-driven learning with worked examples
Key principles: Progressive scaffolding, peer support, authentic tasks
Rationale: CLI skills are best learned through hands-on practice with real tasks, not lectures





Participant-centered: Content responds to what participants need, not a fixed syllabus
Low barrier to entry: No prerequisites, no grades, no penalty for missing sessions
Modular content: Each tutorial stands alone; participants can skip ahead or circle back
Async-first: All content is available on the website; meetings supplement, not replace







Foundation
├── CLI basics (terminal, commands, file operations)
├── Working with paths (absolute, relative, home)
└── Shell configuration (dotfiles, PATH, aliases)

Version control
├── Git fundamentals (init, add, commit, log, diff)
└── GitHub collaboration (remotes, push/pull, PRs)

AI tools
├── Claude Code introduction (install, configure, use)
└── APIs and MCPs (keys, servers, integration)




Foundation: Step-by-step instructions with screenshots and expected output
Version control: Guided exercises with less hand-holding; participants make choices
AI tools: Goal-oriented tasks; participants choose how to accomplish them
Support reduction: Early tutorials say “type this command”; later tutorials say “figure out how to do X”




Each tutorial follows this structure:

Overview — What you’ll learn, prerequisites, estimated time
Concepts — Brief explanation of what and why (not how yet)
Walkthrough — Step-by-step worked example
Practice — Independent exercises with hints
Check your understanding — Self-assessment prompts
Next steps — Links to related tutorials








0–5 min: Check-in, questions from last time
5–15 min: Brief demo of the day’s topic
15–45 min: Guided practice (participants follow along, then try independently)
45–55 min: Open exploration and Q&A
55–60 min: Recap, preview next session, quick feedback





Let participants struggle briefly before helping — productive struggle builds retention
Ask “what did you try?” before giving the answer
Encourage participants to help each other first
Keep demos short; get people typing as fast as possible
Have a backup plan if participants finish early (extension exercises) or get stuck (simpler version)





Pair experienced participants with newer ones
Provide “fast track” notes for those who already know the basics
Offer extension challenges for advanced participants
Keep the main path accessible to the least experienced person in the room








Welcome email/message with link to the workgroup website
Start here: Direct them to the tutorial index, starting with CLI basics
Buddy assignment: Pair with a current participant
First meeting: Arrive 10 minutes early for a quick orientation
Catch-up plan: Work through tutorials at own pace; no need to match the group





GitHub account created
Terminal app located and opened
Workgroup website bookmarked
First tutorial started (CLI basics)







The website is the canonical source of workgroup content. Meetings are supplements.

All topics covered in meetings must have corresponding tutorials on the site
Session notes posted within 48 hours of each meeting
Resources page kept current with links, cheatsheets, and troubleshooting





GitHub Issues: For questions, bug reports, and content requests
Email: For logistics and scheduling
In-person meetings: For hands-on practice and peer interaction








Main branch: Always deployable; content goes live via GitHub Pages
Feature branches: For drafting new tutorials or major changes
Pull requests: Used when participants contribute content
Issues: Track content requests, bugs, and feedback





Participants create their own repos during Git tutorials
Practice PRs and code review on a shared sandbox repo (if interest warrants)
Real collaboration: participants can contribute to the workgroup website








Terminal.app / iTerm2: Primary interface for CLI work
Git: Version control (command-line, not GUI)
GitHub: Remote repos, collaboration, Pages deployment
Claude Code: Agentic AI assistant in the terminal
Text editor: VS Code recommended; any editor acceptable
Quarto: For authoring website content (participants may use this for their own work)





Terminal verification (built into macOS)
Homebrew (macOS package manager)
Git (via Homebrew or Xcode CLI tools)
GitHub account + SSH key setup
Claude Code (via npm or direct install)
VS Code (optional, recommended)








End-of-session check-in: One sentence on what worked and what didn’t
Periodic survey: Every 4–6 sessions, a short written survey
GitHub Issues: Open channel for suggestions and questions anytime
Informal conversation: The facilitator talks to participants





Content adjusted based on what participants find confusing
Session pacing adjusted based on group progress
New topics added when requested
Tutorials revised when feedback identifies gaps








Tutorials tested by running all commands on a clean macOS system
Code blocks verified for accuracy and copy-paste correctness
Links checked periodically for breakage
Participant feedback incorporated within one week





Deploy after each content update via quarto publish gh-pages
Review site navigation quarterly
Archive old session notes (keep on site but deprioritize in navigation)
Keep resource links current








Varied skill levels: Addressed through modular content and peer pairing
Irregular attendance: Addressed through async-first content design
Tool installation issues: Troubleshooting guide on the website; allocate session time for setup help
Participant frustration: Keep early content simple; celebrate small wins; normalize confusion





Website content persists even if meetings pause
Tutorials are reusable for future cohorts
Content is open-source and forkable
No dependency on a single facilitator for async content

title: Workgroup Planning
text:
Workgroup: WFU Agentic AI Workgroup Status: Planning Last Updated: 2026-02-06





Title: Agentic AI Tools in the CLI
Level: Faculty/staff professional development
Discipline: Cross-disciplinary (digital literacy, AI tools)
Prerequisites: None — assumes zero CLI experience





Primary audience: WFU faculty and staff
Expected size: 8–15 active participants (rolling membership)
Background: Varies widely; most have no terminal experience
Diverse needs: Range of comfort with technology, varying schedules





Frequency: Weekly meetings, ongoing (no fixed end date)
Format: In-person meetings + async web content
Meeting duration: ~60 minutes
Tools provided: Workgroup website with tutorials, session notes, and resources








Participants can navigate the file system and execute basic commands in a terminal
Participants can use Git and GitHub for version control
Participants can configure their shell environment
Participants can use Claude Code for agentic coding workflows
Participants can access and configure AI APIs
Participants can set up and use MCP servers
Participants can author documents with Markdown and Quarto





CLI literacy: Comfort working in a terminal environment
Version control: Tracking changes and collaborating via GitHub
AI tool fluency: Using agentic AI assistants effectively
Reproducibility: Creating shareable, reproducible workflows





The workgroup follows a progressive sequence, but participants who join late can catch up via tutorials on the website.



What is a terminal? Why use one?
Navigating the file system (cd, ls, pwd)
Working with files and directories (mkdir, cp, mv, rm)
Reading and editing files from the command line
Understanding paths (absolute vs. relative)





Shell configuration files (.bashrc, .bash_profile, .zshrc)
Environment variables and $PATH
Aliases and shell functions
Package managers (Homebrew on macOS)





Git fundamentals (init, add, commit, log, diff)
Branching and merging
GitHub: remote repos, push/pull, collaboration
Pull requests and code review





Installing and configuring Claude Code
Working with Claude Code in a project
API keys and authentication
MCP servers: what they are and how to use them
Building custom workflows with AI tools





New participants who join after the workgroup has started:

Self-paced tutorials: The website provides written tutorials covering all foundation topics
Buddy system: Pair new participants with someone who’s been attending
Office hours: Facilitator available for one-on-one help
No penalty for gaps: Content is modular; missing sessions doesn’t block progress







Primary approach: Hands-on, task-driven learning
Session structure: Brief demo → guided practice → independent exploration
Scaffolding: Early sessions provide step-by-step instructions; later sessions give goals and let participants find the path
Peer learning: Participants help each other; facilitator is not the only source of knowledge





Modular organization: Each tutorial is self-contained
Progressive difficulty: Foundation → intermediate → advanced
Worked examples: Every concept is illustrated with a concrete task
Real tasks: Use participants’ actual work as practice material when possible




There are no grades. Instead:

Check-your-understanding prompts at the end of tutorials (try this, verify that)
Session feedback: Quick verbal or written check-ins at end of meetings
Self-assessment questions: “Can you do X without looking at the tutorial?”
Peer feedback: Participants review each other’s work in Git/GitHub exercises








A Mac with Terminal.app (or iTerm2)
A GitHub account
A text editor (VS Code recommended but not required)
Claude Code (installed during an early session)





CLI basics tutorial
Path navigation tutorial
Shell configuration tutorial
Git fundamentals tutorial
GitHub collaboration tutorial
Claude Code introduction tutorial
APIs and MCPs tutorial
Cheatsheets for common commands
Troubleshooting guide
Glossary of terms








Attendance: Consistent participation (recognizing rolling membership)
Tutorial completion: Participants working through async content
Peer support: Participants helping each other in and outside meetings
Independent use: Participants using CLI tools in their own work





Coverage: All planned tutorials published and up to date
Clarity: Content is accessible to beginners; feedback incorporated
Usability: Website navigation is intuitive; resources are findable





New member onboarding: New participants can get started independently
Retention: Participants continue attending over time
Skill growth: Observable progression in participant capabilities

title: About
text: The WFU Agentic AI Workgroup is a space for faculty and staff to build hands-on skills with command-line AI tools. The goal is practical fluency: by participating, you’ll be able to use the terminal, manage files with Git, and work with AI assistants like Claude Code in your own projects.

title: About
text: The WFU Agentic AI Workgroup is a space for faculty and staff to build hands-on skills with command-line AI tools. The goal is practical fluency: by participating, you’ll be able to use the terminal, manage files with Git, and work with AI assistants like Claude Code in your own projects.

title: About
text:
Learning goals
By the end of the tutorial sequence, participants will be able to:

Navigate the file system and run commands in a terminal
Use Git and GitHub for version control and collaboration
Configure shell environments and dotfiles
Work with Claude Code (and/or other CLI tools) for agentic coding workflows
Access and configure APIs for AI services
Set up and use MCP servers for tool integration
Author reproducible documents with Markdown and Quarto

title: About
text:
Format

Weekly meetings — Brief demos followed by hands-on practice. Meetings are standalone; missing one doesn’t block your progress.
Async content — All topics are covered in written tutorials on this site. You can learn entirely at your own pace.
Rolling membership — Join anytime. New participants start with the CLI basics tutorial and work forward.
Professional development — Self-assessment prompts in tutorials help you gauge your own progress.

title: About
text:
What you’ll need

A terminal — macOS: Terminal.app (built-in) or iTerm2. Windows: Windows Terminal with PowerShell or Git Bash.
A GitHub account — Sign up free at github.com. Faculty can also apply for GitHub Education benefits, which include Copilot access and private repository extras.
A text editor — VS Code recommended (cross-platform), but any editor works.
Claude Code — Installed during an early session. See the Claude Code docs for details.

title: About
text:
Facilitator
Will Fleeson – Department of Psychology, Wake Forest University
Questions? Open an issue on GitHub or reach out directly.

title: Git fundamentals
text:
Git is a version control system that tracks changes to your files over time. This tutorial covers the core Git workflow: initializing a repository, staging changes, committing snapshots, and reviewing history.
Prerequisites: Shell configuration Estimated time: 30 minutes






Note



Content in progress. Check back soon or attend a workgroup session for a guided walkthrough.

title: Git fundamentals
text:
Git is a version control system that tracks changes to your files over time. This tutorial covers the core Git workflow: initializing a repository, staging changes, committing snapshots, and reviewing history.
Prerequisites: Shell configuration Estimated time: 30 minutes






Note



Content in progress. Check back soon or attend a workgroup session for a guided walkthrough.

title: Claude Code introduction
text:
Claude Code is an agentic AI assistant that runs in your terminal. This tutorial walks through installation, configuration, and basic usage — including how to give Claude Code context about your project and work with it effectively.
Prerequisites: GitHub collaboration Estimated time: 30 minutes






Note



Content in progress. Check back soon or attend a workgroup session for a guided walkthrough.

title: Claude Code introduction
text:
Claude Code is an agentic AI assistant that runs in your terminal. This tutorial walks through installation, configuration, and basic usage — including how to give Claude Code context about your project and work with it effectively.
Prerequisites: GitHub collaboration Estimated time: 30 minutes

title: Shell configuration
text:
Your shell reads configuration files (dotfiles) every time it starts. This tutorial explains how to customize your terminal by editing these files, setting environment variables, and creating aliases for common commands.
Prerequisites: Working with paths Estimated time: 25 minutes






Note



Content in progress. Check back soon or attend a workgroup session for a guided walkthrough.

title: Shell configuration

title: CLI basics
text:
This tutorial introduces the command-line interface (CLI). You’ll learn how to open a terminal on macOS, run basic commands, and create, move, and delete files and directories.
Prerequisites: None Estimated time: 30 minutes






Note



Content in progress. Check back soon or attend a workgroup session for a guided walkthrough.
